page_analysis.text_content:
Setback considerations

Easements
Some easements affect setbacks i.e., setbacks must be measured
from the edge of the easement regardless of the lot line as illustrat-
ed in Fig 16 on this page. Easements that affect setbacks are:
  • Creek easements
  • Public street easements

Note: most public utility easements do not affect setbacks.

Sidewalks
The sidewalk may not indicate the lot line. Often, the street ease-
ment or public right-of-way extends for several feet beyond the
sidewalk. Fig 16 on this page illustrates this common circum-
stance and how the setbacks are affected i.e., they must be mea-
sured from the lot line regardless of the sidewalk.

Oddly shaped lots
For some lots, the setbacks and required yards may not be obvious.
Fig 17 on page 23 indicates the appropriate site plan for lot shapes
about which questions often arise:
  • flag lot (Fig 17 A)
  • corner lot (Fig 17 B)
  • through lot (Fig 17 D)
  • wedge-shaped lot (Fig 17 E)
  • lot with more than four sides (Fig 17 F & G)

Flag & substandard lots
Fig 17 on page 23 also illustrates examples of setbacks that have
been reduced for smaller or oddly shaped lots e.g.,
  • the front setback of a flag lot (Fig 17 A)
  • the street-side yard setback for substandard corner lots that
    are less than 50' wide (Fig 17 C)

Note: The space between the sidewalk
edge and the lot line is part of the public
right of way. It may be 0' or more than
15'. Please ask at the Development
Center.

visual_elements.description: Titled 'Fig 16 Setbacks: easements and sidewalks', this diagram illustrates a rectangular property lot to explain setback rules. It shows a central shaded 'Buildable area' surrounded by a 'Front yard', 'Rear yard', and two 'Interior-side yard's. At the top, a diagonally hatched area is labeled 'Easement', with an annotation specifying it could be a 'Creek or public access easement e.g., street or alley'. At the bottom, a tiled pattern represents a 'Sidewalk' in front of the 'Front yard'. Arrows indicate the setback dimensions. Leader lines connect various parts of the diagram to explanatory notes about how to measure setbacks from easements and lot lines.
visual_elements.location: Top-right to middle of the page

visual_elements.description: A 'Key' or legend is provided below the main diagram, defining the graphical representations used. It is organized in two columns. First column: a solid line for 'Curb', a dashed line for 'Lot line', and a grid pattern for 'Sidewalk'. Second column: a thick grey line for 'Required setbacks', a shaded rectangle for 'Buildable area', and diagonal hatching for 'Easement'.
visual_elements.location: Middle-left of the page, below the main text body

visual_elements.description: A distinct note box with a dark grey background and white text is located in the bottom-right corner. It advises the reader to contact the Santa Clara Valley Water District for information on creek easements.

additional_notes: The page number '22' is printed at the bottom-left corner.
The text 'Note: most public utility easements do not affect setbacks.' is rendered in italics.
The page layout consists of a main text column on the left and a large diagram with associated annotations on the right. A special note box is in the bottom right.
